title: British Trading Post
listingDescription: The outline of a Trading Post that was established here in 1690 for trade between the British and the Muscogee (Creek).

images.altText: A wooden outline of the foundation of the trading post in a grassy field.
images.title: British Trading Post
images.caption: Outline of the British Trading Post

bodyText:
The British Trading Post was established in 1690, and consisted of a five-sided stockade and two interior buildings. The longest wall paralleled the ancient trading path adjacent to it and had two openings, probably gates. The smallest ‘gate’ was five feet in length and possibly used for pedestrian traffic. The length of the second ‘gate’ suggests use for the pack horses loaded with incoming trading goods and outgoing deer skins.

Most trading posts of this era had a building for trading, including merchandise storage and a warehouse for storing the deer skins prior to shipment. Excavations at the site revealed Indian construction techniques (wattle and daub) consistent with the practice of using Indian labor. The smaller building was approximately 11 x 11 feet and adjacent to the largest entrance. A second structure was in the southwestern area of the stockade and measured 15 x 25 feet.
audioDescription: A large grassy field with a five-sided wooden outline depicting the shape of the British Trading Post's foundations.

quickFacts.value: Location of a trading post used in the 1700s.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Civil War Earthworks
listingDescription: During “The War Between the States” the young city of Macon was threatened with destruction on two separate occasions when Union and Confederate forces met just across the river from the city. Both conflicts took place on the grounds of Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park. Today, one of the few surviving Civil War earthworks in Macon remains in the park; a reminder of another time in history adding to the heritage that is Ocmulgee.

images.altText: A small grassy mound in an open field at the edge of a patch of trees.
images.title: Civil War Earthworks
images.caption: Civil War Earthworks

bodyText:
The Civil War earthworks were constructed after the Battle of Dunlap Hill, which took place July 30, 1864. The earthworks were used again that same year in November during the Battle of Walnut Creek. They are one of a few surviving Civil War earthworks in Macon.

The Civil War earthworks are at the end of the Dunlap Trail, which is 1/4th of a mile long and begins across the park road from the Visitor Center. The earthworks are near the Dunlap Mound and Dunlap House, which is now a private residence.
audioDescription: A small grassy mound in a field with a patch of trees behind it. A park bench and wayside are in front of the earthworks.

quickFacts.value: One of the few surviving Civil War earthworks in Macon.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Clay Pond
listingDescription: A hotspot for wildlife viewing, Clay Pond offers a great view into the wetlands environment of Ocmulgee Mounds.

images.altText: A roughly circular pond surrounded by trees.
images.title: Clay Pond
images.caption: Clay Pond

bodyText: Clay Pond is an important part of the wetlands here in Ocmulgee Mounds, and has abundant wildlife viewing opportunities, including birding. You may see egrets, osprey, herrings, and anhinga just to name a few. During the summer months you might also be able to see turtles or even an alligator sunning on one of the logs in the pond. Clay Pond is visible from the Opelofa Trail, the park road, and the Great Temple Mound.
audioDescription: A roughly circular pond in a wetlands environment surrounded by trees.

quickFacts.value: An important habitat for many of the park's wildlife species.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Cornfield Mound
listingDescription: A ceremonial cornfield adjacent to the Earth Lodge.

images.altText: A grassy hill with various depressions lining one side.
images.title: Cornfield Mound
images.caption: Cornfield Mound

bodyText: The Cornfield Mound is believed to have originally been a ceremonial cornfield. Later the mound was built over the field. During the excavation of the mound, archaeologists discovered charred corncobs and a layer of rolling topsoil in parallel rows under the mound. The parallel rows indicated a cultivated field used by the Mississippians; who not only grew corn, but also beans, squash, sunflowers, and tobacco in fields closer to the river.
audioDescription: A gently sloping grassy mound with one side smooth and the other full of sunken depressions.

quickFacts.value: A ceremonial cornfield for the Mississippians.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Dunlap House
listingDescription: In 1856, Samuel S. Dunlap constructed this house as part of his 400-acre cotton plantation. On July 30, 1864, the Dunlap house was occupied by Union troops during the Battle of Dunlap Hill, part of Stoneman’s Raid. After the war, Captain Dunlap turned the plantation into a dairy farm. This area is not open to the public.

images.altText: A square white house with trees and flowering shrubs on either side of it.
images.title: Dunlap House
images.caption: The Dunlap House

bodyText:
In 1856, Samuel S. Dunlap constructed this house as part of his 400-acre cotton plantation. On July 30, 1864, the Dunlap house was occupied by Union troops during the Battle of Dunlap Hill, part of Stoneman’s Raid. After the war, Captain Dunlap turned the plantation into a dairy farm.

In the late 1930s the Dunlap house served as an office for the National Park Service staff of Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park. In 1940, the office was moved into the new administration building and the house was converted into the superintendent’s residence. In the early 1950s, the house was remodeled to its present appearance. Today, the Dunlap house is still used as a residence for park staff, and is one of the oldest houses in Macon.

title: Earth Lodge
listingDescription: Visitors experience a view of the ancient past when they enter the Earth Lodge, a reconstructed council chamber of the Mississippian culture. The clay floor inside is the original floor, making it over 1,000 years old.

images.altText: A view of the grass-covered Earth Lodge and the wooden doorway.
images.title: Earth Lodge Entrance
images.caption: Earth Lodge Entrance

bodyText:
Visitors experience a view of the ancient past when they enter the Earth Lodge, a reconstructed council chamber of the Mississippian culture. This building’s walls and ceiling were reconstructed in the late 1930’s by Civilian Conservation Corp and Works Project Administration crews under the direction of Archeologist A.R. Kelly. The clay floor within this building is the original floor built by native people. It is dated, using carbon dating techniques, at the year 1015. 

The Earth Lodge is a short walk from the Visitor Center parking lot.
audioDescription: The exterior is a circular earthen lodge covered in green grass with a rectangle entrance that is 26 inches high and 24.5 inches wide. The entrance is constructed of pine logs and has a door made of woven reeds. The interior includes the original clay floor. Formed into the floor was a circle of 50 seats against the circular walls of the lodge, a large fire pit in the center of the room, and a bird effigy in the center of the back wall opposite the entrance. The circle is divided by the long, low entrance and the bird effigy. Three of the seats are positioned on top of the massive clay image of a bird.

quickFacts.value: Reconstructed earth lodge with original 1,000-year-old clay floor.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Funeral Mound
listingDescription: This mound was built in seven stages to be a burial ground for the elite members of the Mississippian society. Please do not walk on this mound.

images.altText: A grassy mound with trees behind it.
images.title: Funeral Mound Spring
images.caption: Funeral Mound

bodyText:
The Funeral Mound was built as a burial ground for the elite members of the Mississippian society. It was built in seven stages and was originally nearly 50 ft. tall. Presently, it stands at only 20 ft. tall because of railroad construction in the 1870's. Please do not walk on this mound.

The Funeral Mound is at the end of the park road, next to one of the park's parking lots. The parking lot is also the trailhead for the Funeral Loop trail, a half-mile loop through woods on the opposite side of the parking lot as the Funeral Mound.
audioDescription: A twenty-foot-tall, grassy mound that is surrounded by a small field of grass and a line of trees behind it.

quickFacts.value: The burial spot of elite members of Mississippian society.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Great Temple Mound Complex
listingDescription: Consisting of the two tallest mounds in the park, the Great Temple Mound Complex is where the chief and second-chief would have lived during the Mississippian Period, and offers a beautiful view of the surrounding area from atop the mounds.

images.altText: Two grassy mounds in an open field with the park road running in front of them.
images.title: Great and Lesser Temple Mounds
images.caption: A view of the Great and Lesser Temple Mounds

bodyText: The Great Temple Mound Complex consists of the two tallest mounds in the park: The Great Temple Mound and the Lesser Temple Mound. These mounds were created by the Mississippians who lived here in the 10<sup>th</sup> century CE. The flat-topped, pyramidal mounds were raised in layers at intervals over many years; and suggest intricate social relationships. The Great Temple Mound is where the village chief would have lived, and was built in four separate stages with clay steps going up the northern slope. It’s estimated that 10 million baskets of dirt, weighing about 60 pounds each, were used to build the 55-feet-tall mound! Today, there are steps that allow visitors to climb to the top of both mounds for a spectacular view of the surrounding area.
audioDescription: Two grass-covered mounds side by side. The taller one on the right is fifty-five feet high, and is the Great Temple Mound. The smaller one on the left, the Lesser Temple Mound, is ten feet high. Wooden steps built by park staff allow visitors to climb to the top of both mounds.

quickFacts.value: Tallest two mounds in the park; where the chief and second-chief lived during the Mississippian Period.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: McDougal Mound
listingDescription: Located near the old park entrance, this mound is named after a captain stationed at nearby Fort Hawkins in 1809.

images.altText: A grassy mound on top of a small hill.
images.title: McDougal Mound
images.caption: McDougal Mound

bodyText:
This mound is named after Captain Robert McDougal, who was in command of Fort Hawkins in 1809. McDougal died in 1809, and according to legend, was buried in a small Indian mound near the fort, but archaeologists did not find any human remains in this mound during the excavations in the 1930s. There were three smaller mounds between the McDougal Mound and the fort which were destroyed during expansion and construction of Macon.

The McDougal Mound is located at the end of the McDougal Trail, which is accessed off of the Heritage Trail in the park.
audioDescription: A grassy mound at the top of a small hill.

quickFacts.value: One of the mounds built by the Mississippians.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Mound X
listingDescription: A Mississippian mound that is no longer visible.

images.altText: An open grassy area where a Mississippian mound once stood.
images.title: Mound X
images.caption: Mound X

bodyText: Mound X is no longer visible. The first evidence of the mound's existence was in an 1806 survey of the area along with other mounds in the park. In the 1930s, an excavation was conducted in the mound area, which was about three feet high at the time. The excavators dug seven trenches and discovered an area of tan sand over a sod layer that in turn overlays a dark tan sand layer some 70 feet wide. The mound was constructed outside of the Mississippian village's fortifications, suggesting that the mound was built near the end of the Mississippian period after the village had expanded.
audioDescription: An open grassy field surrounded by trees.

quickFacts.value: Location of a Mississippian mound found in the park.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Ocmulgee Mounds Association Bookstore
listingDescription: The park store is operated by the Ocmulgee Mounds Association, an official non-profit partner of the National Park Service dedicated to supporting the educational mission of Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park. The park store has a wide range of books, magnets, postcards, and other items available for retail sale.

images.altText: The entrance to the park store with several merchandise items displayed outside the doorway.
images.title: Park Store Entrance
images.caption: Park Store Entrance

bodyText: The park store is operated by the Ocmulgee Mounds Association, an official non-profit partner of the National Park Service dedicated to supporting the educational mission of Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park. The park store has a wide range of books, magnets, postcards, and other items available for retail sale. These products complement the interpretive themes you experience when visiting the park. The park store is located at the park visitor center, or you can visit the online park store.
audioDescription: A park bookstore with merchandise such as books, magnets, postcards, etc.

title: Southeast Mound
listingDescription: One of the lesser-known mounds in the park, the Southeast Mound was likely built near the end of the Mississippian period.

images.altText: A small grassy mound surrounded by trees.
images.title: Southeast Mound
images.caption: Southeast Mound

bodyText:
The Southeast Mound remains a bit of a mystery to archaeologists. Not much is known about the mound. Its oval shape suggests heavy damage from erosion and ploughing before the 1930s. Today, the mound measures three feet high. The mound was likely built near the end of the Mississippian period since it was built outside of the village fortifications; hinting that the village expanded beyond the originial fortifications over time.

The Southeast Mound is located at the end of the Southeast Mound trail and at one end of the Bartram Trail (either the beginning or end, depending on which way you start).
audioDescription: A small, three-foot-high grassy mound surrounded by trees.

quickFacts.value: One of the mounds built by the Mississippians.
quickFacts.name: Significance
